title: 114_hr6017
content: The "Race to the Job Initiative Act" is established. The "Race to the Job Initiative Act" establishes a grant program for eligible low-income communities for community development. The Secretary of the Treasury will select 30 communities in the first year and an additional 20 in the second year, with a limit of 3 communities per state. To receive grants under section 3, eligible low-income communities must submit an application to the Secretary, including specifying a community development financial institution for capital assistance. The application should also describe how the community has experienced concentrated poverty. The development proposal for eligible low-income communities must include plans to use grant funds to improve the economy, benefit disadvantaged populations, and establish or expand anchor institutions without displacing residents. The Secretary will prioritize awarding grants to eligible low-income communities with high poverty rates. The communities must target high-growth sectors, provide affordable financial services, and identify potential investors for matching funds. "Grants will be awarded to eligible low-income communities with high poverty rates, focusing on high-growth sectors and providing affordable financial services." The Secretary will award grants to eligible low-income communities for anchor institution grants, which can be used to establish or expand anchor institutions with a limitation of 25% of total costs covered by the grant funds. Funds awarded under this paragraph are for establishing or expanding anchor institutions in eligible low-income communities, specifically for job training programs serving residents of those communities. Anchor institutions are defined as hospitals, colleges, research centers, nonprofit institutions, or others specified by the Secretary. $100,000,000 is authorized for grants in fiscal year 2017. Infrastructure grants under this program are to be used for public infrastructure improvement projects in eligible low-income communities, with a limitation that grant funds cannot exceed 10% of the total project cost. $200,000,000 is authorized for grants in fiscal year 2017, with funds remaining available until expended. Technical assistance grants under this program are to be used for providing technical assistance and are authorized to receive $20,000,000 for fiscal year 2017, with funds remaining available until expended. The Secretary will award capital assistance grants to community development financial institutions in eligible low-income communities to make loans and investments. $200,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2017. Additionally, a tax credit for community investment is introduced. The amendment to Section 45D of the Internal Revenue Code allows partner community development financial institutions in eligible low-income communities to be treated as qualified community development entities without allocation limitations. The amendments made by this section apply to partner community development financial institutions in eligible low-income communities selected by the Secretary under section 2(b) after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 6. INCREASE IN CDFI AWARD AMOUNTS. Section 108(d) of the Community Development Banking and Financial Institutions Act of 1994 is amended to include a limitation on annual financial assistance for community development financial institutions receiving a capital assistance grant under the Race to the Job Initiative Act. The Fund may not provide more than $10,000,000 in annual financial assistance to such institutions and their subsidiaries and affiliates. The Community Development Banking and Financial Institutions Act of 1994 is amended to limit annual financial assistance for community development financial institutions under the Race to the Job Initiative Act to $10,000,000 and $500,000 in annual technical assistance. SEC. 7. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, the term "community development financial institution" is defined as per the Riegle Community Development and Regulatory Improvement Act of 1994. An "eligible low-income community" is a city or county with a poverty rate of at least 30% and an unemployment rate at least 150% of the national average. The term "State" refers to each of the several states. The term "State" includes all states, the District of Columbia, and any U.S. commonwealth, territory, or possession.
